properties.media:imagetext:
SHANGHAI
CHINA
MARCH 15, 1933
Dear Bixbys
second movie in three days
therefore will at least
make a start on a letter.
We, Pawley and Polin, went to see
I cannot recommend it as a part of the entertainment program for a
convent. Maybe the
condon on t as a tive to china as the U.S. Anyway it was plenty rough.
nesday. On Monday we went to see John Barrymore in
way of thinking
A Bill of Divorcement" which to my
is a great movie. Afterwards we went to a new Chinese dance hall which
has just been started. The building is a one story affair elaborately decorated in the
most approved ( by Skouras Bros. ) style - thoroughly American.
The hall is about one
hundred and fifty feet square. There are no posts at all. Around the edge of the large
dance floor are tables where you can sit and order drinks, the tables being arranged in
rows about three deep. A sign as you enter announces in several languages
uniforms are not admitted. At one end an American jazz band of women musicians, music
lovers might object to that description, who played all the very latest American jazz
music.
Immediately around the hall seated on chairs there was a row of Chinese "host-
esses" who dance with the guests for ten cents Mex per dance. There were at least two
hundred Chinese and foreigners present. No one was drunk,
in fact I have not yet seen
anyone full in China except some of our countrymen,
and those appeared to be on one of
the
many cruises which put into Shanghai for one or two days. Many of the Chinese girls
of the hostess variety and also others who came with escorts, wear American clothes.
Most of them dance very well, but the men aremostly in the beginner class. They are
awfully funny, perfectly dead in earnest, no exchange of small talk, no change in ex-
pression and apparently they are bored to death - except that they are very Scotch -
and certainly would not be there if they were not getting what they consider their
moneys worth. I danced with two of the hostessess - one at a time - and they were as
good as either Gloria or Lucy Bixby
- I mean as dancers. They tried to talk a few words
of some language possibly English
but I couldn't make out what it was all about. Anyone
over here who is not Chinese is a "foreigner", the Chinese not being able to tell an
American from an Englidhman, Frenchman or what have you, One girl who knew Mr. Polin
was named Mary McTavish, her Father was unit a Scotchman, as you might guess by her name,
and her Mother was Chinese. She is quite pretty and works as a stenographer for one of
Mr. Polinis friends. These Eurasians, as any offspring of mixed races is called out
way of thinking most unfortunate. They are frequently disowned by both
whose Grandfather was English, Grandmother Indian - thats too long a story to write out
the net of it is that she is a combination of English, Indian,
Chinese, Japanese and
Italian and will probably marry a Greek - so figure that out. The famous statement of
Bill Robertsons to Harry
Guggenheim that one nice thing about China was that "there were
no Jews over there" is like most of Bill's statements not entirely correct. Mr. Polin
is a perfect peach, but he should not eat ham. He introduced us to another Irishman by
the name of Ginsburg who with a crowd of fellow Welshmen,
Solomon and Strauss were
seated at a nearby
table. We had a lot of fun and I wish Bo and Frances could have seen
me stepping around with my accustomed grace with those Chinese girls.
They wore the
conventional Chinese dress with high collar which would make Queen Mary's costumes 100k
positively indecent. I felt like George Merck dancing with Jane Hotchkiss, or Theron
Catlin with Kitty Guy - take your pick.
Had tea Tuesday with Perry Hutton who called me up when he arrived here
with the ex-Marshal Chang Hsieu-liang. Perry is an old barn storming pilot who hails
Iron wichita kansas.
and used to be out at Lambert Field frequently. He came over here
originally with a trimotor Ford to demonstrate in Japan and China. He sold the Ford to
the Young Marshalt, and stayed on as his personal pilot. The Marshal as you probably
have read has resigned as the war lord of North China because he has been charged with
the loss of Jehol, and now Perry will fly him on a pleasure trip to Europe, or may do
so a little later on. Hutton has been with the Marshal for three years and has some
great stories to tell about being shot at, trips where a forced landing would have
meant the massacre of the whole crowd, etc. He also told me some of the inside story on
the operations in Jehol which were very interesting.
Must turn in now and get a little sleep. By the way have you heard how
the Charleston was invented? The inventor saw a Scotchman in front of a pay toilet,
Station HM B
Shanghai signing off
